question: Ah ha! Here we are! Aramis! Porthos is here! Aaaaaaaramis!! Porthos is -- Sorry, my dears. You would have enjoyed it too. He's hung like a donkey. Really? I haven't been able to see it for fifteen years. Go on now, leave His Holiness alone. I'll bring you back tomorrow when he's in a better mood. Please revel with me, Aramis, I need my spirits lifted. I'm old, I'm weak, my strength is gone --
answer: Be quiet, you fat fool. Can't you see I'm praying?

question: I just said you're praying! Are you deaf too? I know you're blind, because if you had seen the tits that just walked out of here, you'd have tears in your eyes.
answer: There are more important things than tits.

question: Really? If you can name me one thing, one single thing, that is more sublime than the feel of a plump pink nipple between my lips, I will buy you a new cathedral.
answer: Forgiveness.

question: Forgiveness? Forgive me. Am I forgiven? I observe your forgiveness isn't sweeter than a plump nipple.
answer: Can't you see I'm praying, goddammit?!

question: How are you, you skinny little pup!
answer: A simple theological discussion.

question: Do I look all right?
answer: None of the ladies will be able to take their eyes off you.

question: I care only about Michelle. Should I ask her when we first arrive? Or... or when we're leaving? I could ask her in the carriage -- but it is more romantic at the palace. I get so confused...
answer: Perhaps this will help.

question: Mother's ring. I can't take this.
answer: She died giving you to me. And I want to die knowing it is one the finger of the women my son loves. Now go, and bring back your fiance.

question: Yes! It is our duty to let you know... there are riots in Paris.
answer: Riots? My people live in the world's most beautiful city, their king has the grandest palaces on earth. Why should they feel anything but pride and contentment?

question: Well yes, of course, Majesty, and I'm sure they are content... except that... well, they are starving.
answer: Sometimes the poor do grow hungry. But why would they riot about it?

question: Majesty... We have more than enough food set aside for your birthday celebration next week. If we distributed some of that, we would have time to gather more before --
answer: Aramis! I have been expecting you! We are satisfied, that will do.

question: Aramis! I have been expecting you! We are satisfied, that will do.
answer: Your birthday celebration, your Majesty?

question: Next week. This is a mere garden party -- and I wish to join it, so I will be brief. I am experiencing resistance from the Jesuits.
answer: Well... perhaps you should speak with them, your Majesty.

question: I have demanded it -- and common priests present themselves! Can you imagine the arrogance? Common Jesuit priests try to act as my equals, and they refuse to reveal the names of anyone else in their order! No one can keep secrets like the Jesuits can, and the identity of their leader is the darkest secret they hold. Even the Pope himself does not know who leads the Jesuit Order in France! He suspects the Governor General of Jesuits, whoever he is, is angling to become Pope himself.
answer: How can I serve you in this?

question: Perhaps you can find out who this secret leader of the Jesuits is. You are now a priest, but you were once a Musketeer, serving the throne of France, a throne ordained of God. Can you accept this mission, and keep it private?
answer: If I find out the identity of this Jesuit rebel. I will kill both him and the man who told me.

question: Who is that? Not the soldier, you idiot!
answer: is presiding over a huddle of fresh faced young Musketeers, directing them to their positions around the gardens, like secret service agents protecting a president. He leaves them, and quickly moves to the King. Your Majesty...

question: What is it, d'Artagnan? Assassins falling from the sky now?
answer: The plans for use of the maze were not disclosed to me.

question: I decided it this morning.
answer: Then you must allow me to stay close to you so that --

question: I am King, d'Artagnan. I will change my mind as I wish, and I will enjoy my banquet as I wish!
answer: But I deployed the Royal Guards according to your previous --

question: Food, moron.
answer: Thank you, Keeper.

question: Look what you've done!
answer: I'm sorry, Keeper... No, Keeper, it's my only book! What number did you tear out?

question: Eh?
answer: What number, on the first page?

question: ... Two-thirty-seven.
answer: Two-thirty-seven

question: You've... memorized...?
answer: What was the end page? Six-two-one We're playing, Keeper! A game! Take another page, any page! Keeper and I are playing a game! A game, a game, we're playing a -- Keeper...? No... No! Keeper, please, you cannot die! You're my only friend! Help! Someone! Keeper is dead!

question: M'lady...?
answer: I understand you saved my son's life today.

question: God smiled upon us.
answer: And you were not hurt?

question: No, M'lady.
answer: That is good.

question: D'Artagnan!
answer: Athos, my friend! It's been too long.

question: Life is too long. Except when we have our friends. Look at you! You're still a boy! Sit, sit! I'll open a bottle of wine.
answer: Thanks, but not for me.

question: You can't drink with a friend you haven't seen in months?
answer: I have ordered a drill of the Royal Guard for midnight, and must be clear-headed for it.

question: Midnight! Mon dieu! Driving the youngsters hard, eh?
answer: They must stay sharp. There was an attempt on the King's life today.

question: Another? How many times have you saved his life in this year alone? Three? Four?
answer: I heard your playing.

question: I was feeling sorry for myself. Raoul is getting married, he proposed today! I love that boy beyond all measure, I've spent everything I own to give him education and opportunity. Now he has complete happiness, and I mope.
answer: Athos...

question: That must be Raoul! Raoul! Look, d'Artagnan's come to visit...! What's wrong? You look awful!
answer: Michelle, she -- The king has invited her to come live in the palace.

question: But -- are you sure?
answer: We were at her door. I was just taking the ring from my pocket, for the third time today, when a young Musketeer brought the invitation for her to become a lady-in-waiting for the Queen Mother.

question: Michelle cannot possibly accept!
answer: She cannot possibly refuse. Her family is poor, they have even less money than we do. And along with the invitation, the King sent the diamond pendant, from the piglet.

question: Piglet -- ? What are you -- ?
answer: Never mind, Papa, it doesn't matter now. She loved me once. I want to die remembering that.

question: Die? What...?
answer: I have rejoined the army, and asked to resume my commission at the head of the troops of General Fromberge.

question: Fromberge...?! At the front?! No.
answer: It is already done. I have just stopped at Mother's grave, to say goodbye, before coming to tell you.

question: Raoul, no... You cannot do this. No matter how your heart is broken --
answer: Goodbye, father. I am sorry.

question: Raoul -- This cannot be. Everyone knows the Queen Mother is a recluse, and the ladies-in-waiting are but mistresses for the king!
answer: If the young woman truly loves Raoul --

question: She's a woman, d'Artagnan! From a poor family. You may still be young enough to believe love conquers everything, but I am old and hard and I've seen too much. Even when kings are hunchbacks they have any woman they desire, because power seduces even more than love! You knew this was happening. You knew and that's why you came.
answer: I fear I know our King. I came to try to bring you hope.

question: What hope is there? A wartime commission cannot be vacated except by the king, and what chance is there of that? Fromberge is on the battle line, and Raoul --
answer: I have dispatches a message to Fromberge requesting that Raoul be kept far from the fighting.

question: Raoul is everything to me.
answer: I know.

question: Oh my friend.
answer: I will also speak with the King, for he is surely unaware of the problems his invitation to Mademoiselle Beaufort has caused.

question: You trust his character more than anyone else does.
answer: Raoul is hurrying to the front, so I must hurry too.

question: This stuff stinks. It is rotting! The King gives us rotten food!
answer: No! Run to the palace and close the gates. But do not fire!

question: Come on! To the palace! One Musketeer can't stop us!
answer: Stop you? You are Frenchmen, are you not? I am one of you.

question: The King is a Frenchman, but he is not one of us!
answer: Citizens of Paris! Give ear to me!

question: We'll give you their ears!
answer: Wait -- and listen! I beg you! I'm on my way to a salad! Doesn't anybody have any endive? A tomato? You are right. It is rotten. I will speak to the King myself. You have my word. And you will release those men -- for they serve France... and you.

question: I'm hungry. I like to eat alone. By the way, you'll be moving tomorrow. Aaa! D'Artagnan! These passages were constructed for the King's security, not so you could step from my father's portrait and startle me to death!
answer: It is for your security that I have come, your Majesty -- for the security of your honor.

question: I already know about the riots, d'Artagnan, I heard them out there whispering. Some fool gave the order to distribute rotten food. I will deal with it tomorrow.
answer: Then there is one more thing, of an even more personal nature.

question: A personal nature?
answer: Mademoiselle Michelle Beaufort. She is betrothed to Raoul, the son of Athos the Musketeer, who has served France through many tribulations.

question: Betrothed? I think not.
answer: In his mind, anyway, and soon enough in hers. She had written him many letters of love.

question: Miss Beaufort has accepted our invitation. By this we can only suppose that she wishes to come -- as we wish her to be here.
answer: Your Majesty has had many women --

question: That is my desire, and my desire is what should concern you, not the sentiments of some commoner!
answer: It is not Raoul's heart alone that concerns me. It is yours. I know you find women compliant -- especially the poorer ones like Michelle. But do they love you? Do you love them? What about a queen to love? A son of your own?

question: What quaint notions, d'Artagnan! But they contradict my father, who picked his queen when he was old, and only then to bear me.
answer: There is more to love than he knew, or that you know.

question: You dare criticize my father?! Or lecture me?!
answer: Not criticize -- plead. Love. Love your people, and you will not bear to see them hungry. Love women, and they will love you. Love yourself, and --

question: That is enough! You are a good servant, d'Artagnan, but you forget your place!
answer: At least help Raoul.

question: Silence! I order you!
answer: Order Fromberge to keep him in safety! It is the least you can do, to protect your own honor!

question: I will consider it. Now leave me.
answer: Thank you, your Majesty.

question: Well done, Pierre. It will be good for your soul, that you have taken responsibility for your errors. And don't worry, I will look after your family. Do not rejoice -- but know that your King does not tolerate blunders that hurt his beloved people. More food is on its way, and my advisors tell me the new harvests are sure to be bountiful! And I have new joys to announce to you! Today we decree a fresh glory for Paris, and for all of France! The laying of the foundations to expand Versailles, and make it truly a palace of the sun!
answer: Your Majesty...

question: How goes that favor I asked of you?
answer: I grow closer to my target, your Majesty.

question: You bring me the heart of the Jesuit General, and you will have a palace of your own.
answer: Raoul! The army! Oh Raoul, don't despair! I will always be faithful... Sire! I -- How did you --

question: How did I get in? You're new here, and will soon learn many secrets. What is that?
answer: ... Nothing.

question: A letter. May I see? From Raoul. He urges you to guard your honor -- as if it could be in any danger... from your king.
answer: Raoul... is in love...

question: Enough of this, our dinner waits. The food doesn't please you?
answer: It's lovely. It's just...

question: This is more than you are used to. Your mother is a seamstress, your father is dead. You have three younger sisters, two of whom suffer from consumption. Don't look so surprised, Kings know such things.
answer: I... we are humble people...

question: Wait, no! Do not be ashamed. The straits of your family need not be permanent. It is a simple matter to have them brought to one of my country estates, where they may have fine meals, and physicians to look after them.
answer: You would do that, your Majesty?

question: My dear, I've already done it. Please, darling, that isn't necessary. We are friends now. Mademoiselle needs wine! You are beautiful. You know you are.
answer: Sire, I --

question: No, no, no... Saddle my horse! Hurry -- Athos, my friend -- Athos, please...!
answer: Get out of my way.

question: Athos, I beg you -- Where are you going?
answer: To kill the king.

question: Athos! I know life means nothing to you at this moment, but I will not let you kill yourself.
answer: The King killed my son!

question: The cannons killed Raoul! The cannons, and love. But not the King.
answer: Come on! All of you! Coward! Fight me! Fight me...! He killed my son, d'Artagnan! He killed my son...!

question: No, you may wait behind the screen.
answer: I would not have disturbed you, Majesty, but you ordered me to keep you informed --

question: Yes, yes, go on.
answer: Athos, the former Musketeer, has just fought with several of your guard, at the Musketeers' Gate.

question: Did they kill him?
answer: No. He cut an ear from one of the men, no one else was hurt. Captain d'Artagnan allowed him to leave. Athos was upset about the death of his son, at the front.

question: Who was Athos seeking? Tell me! Did he try to enter the palace?
answer: ... He did -- but Captain d'Artagnan blocked his way.

question: You may go, Lieutenant.
answer: Do you want Athos arrested, your Majesty?

question: Aramis... is this the way to hell?
answer: Hell may be our destination, dear Porthos, but not this trip.

question: Where are we?
answer: Jesus of Nazareth found the holy among the profane. If we are to have a place of private prayer, where better than here, beside the channels where the shit and the garbage run to the river?

question: Mother of God!
answer: It is also a place of burial.

question: A tomb? We're in a tomb?
answer: Catacombs. Very holy.

question: Yaaaahhh!
answer: Relax, you big fool, it's d'Artagnan. It's all right. D'Artagnan was the one who warned us that he'd been given an order for your arrest. Here you have sanctuary -- does he not, d'Artagnan? Look at us. We are old men now. But once we were young. And when we saw injustice, we fought it.

question: Well here is the problem at hand
answer: But -- doesn't God ordain both Pope and King?

question: So they tell us. But what are we to believe when the king is a tyrant, and the Church, meant to stand for all those oppressed, has become the tool of oppression? When no conscience is tolerated? No dissent, no objection?
answer: It is a weighty problem, Aramis -- but perhaps you should leave it to this secret General of the Jesuits, whoever he might be.

question: You -- You cannot ask me to betray my king! I have sworn to him!
answer: It is honor you serve, and when the king is dishonorable you are removed from your oath of honor!

question: An oath is an oath precisely because it cannot be removed!
answer: Why do you follow him, d'Artagnan?! I know you have put service above your own life, but why does this King deserve such loyalty? He is a monster! He executes ministers for his own blunders, with their families hostage so they take the blame! He has no honor!

question: No man is all bad... or all good. I believe -- I must believe -- that Louis can learn. And perhaps I can help him.
answer: Whatever the plan... I am in it! The next time we meet, one of us will die.

question: Porthos sleeps, and you plot. Don't you think it's time you told me what it is you are plotting?
answer: Soon enough. Here we are.

question: The Prison of Belle Sur.
answer: Come, we have a boat waiting.

question: What is that?
answer: A body.

question: I see that is a body! But where did you get it?
answer: He gets one day of confession each year. Today is the day.

question: Who does?
answer: Best not to ask. Shouldn't even talk about it.

question: What do we do now?
answer: I don't know about you, but I plan to wait here.

question: My confession day! But where is the other one? I know you don't speak my language -- but is the other one all right? Please tell me he is not dead too, or I will have lost everyone. I... tore my Bible. Or someone else did. But it was all right. "Let the words of my mouth and the meditations of my heart be acceptable in Thy sight, Oh Lord our God and My Redeemer." I'm sorry. You're never seen me before. I must frighten you. What are you doing? Why do you --
answer: I am a friend, here to help you.

question: What -- ?
answer: It is an escape. To freedom.

question: Freedom...? Wh-- ? He is dead! Who is he?
answer: He is you. Hey! Hey!

question: What is wrong? We only mean to free you from the mask!
answer: Prison was horrible but it was his home. He's been torn from it by strangers. He's frightened, exhausted -- and the mask is familiar. Let him rest in it tonight, and remove it tomorrow.

question: Excellent, Athos. You have a keen sense of this man.
answer: His plight is obvious, isn't it?

question: Are you hungry?
answer: Just... water. This way. This place... I once lived in a country house. I had guardians -- an old man and woman. And tutors. But no friends. Then when I was twelve, they came and took me to the prison.

question: Who came?
answer: A man in black. I never saw his face. He took me to the cell. A blacksmith came and they put me into the mask. For days I shouted, "What have I done? Why do you do this to me?" But no one heard, so I just stopped shouting.

question: And you never knew why? What is your name?
answer: The old man and woman called me... Phillippe.

question: Phillippe. Rest now.
answer: Thank you... for your kindness.

question: Who is he, Aramis?
answer: Tomorrow.

question: Tonight! Right now! We steal a man from a royal prison, we hide in a country chateau among an assortment of saints and sluts such as only you could provide, and still you wish to tell me nothing?!
answer: You seek facts, when it would be better to seek truth.

question: You are not my priest, Aramis! You would not be, even if I had one.
answer: You are bitter, Athos. You are torn by grief, not only for Raoul, but for d'Artagnan, whom you love, and now treat as an enemy.

question: He who is not with us is against us.
answer: Those are the words of a broken spirit. My spirit is whole. I have trusted d'Artagnan with my deepest secrets, and I will never believe he is my enemy.

question: Then you are a fool -- a fool who has never lost a son. What gives you the right to judge me, to play God with the lives of others? Is it because you are so much holier than everyone else?!
answer: There is that, of course -- but mainly it is because I am so much smarter than everyone else. Porthos?!

question: Oh God I -- Forgive me...
answer: M'lady...? What -- ?

question: No, stay back! Stay back! D'Artagnan!
answer: M'lady... if anyone sees, it is death...

question: If I don't kiss you, I die anyway.
answer: I can't bear to see you cry. What is wrong?

question: Nothing... Nothing. Nothing. This... didn't happen. I must go back now.
answer: Anne...! I know... I know that to love you is treason against France. But not to love you... is treason against my heart.

question: What is wrong? What is wrong?!
answer: Raoul... Oh, Raoul...

question: Listen, my darling... Raoul was a... a good friend. And now he is dead and that is very sad but --
answer: We'll burn in hell. Both of us.

question: I have never forgotten that night, or what I carried.
answer: I don't understand. What does this have to do with...? You carried a baby somewhere, it's unusual, but --

question: Not just a baby, Porthos. I carried the child of the king.
answer: The child of the king is... the king. Louis!

question: No, not Louis!
answer: Athos, do you understand this? He confuses me --

question: I carried the king's child! The queen had twins that night, and one of them was sent away, in secret!
answer: But why?

question: We will replace Louis with Phillippe. No one but the King himself -- and now we -- knows Phillippe even exists. All we have to do is switch them.
answer: Switch?! That is your plan? It is ludicrous!

question: I have it all worked out.
answer: Physical resemblance is but one small thing! Louis has an arrogance, a manner --

question: Those can be adopted --
answer: And people close to him, who --

question: Do you think I have not considered that? I have a plan -- and you may rest assured that it is brilliant!
answer: It is not just our lives you risk with this conceit of yours! It is Phillippe's as well!

question: Recent hours have been a shock.
answer: Perhaps not as much as you might imagine. When tutors answered every question except those about who I was. When I was imprisoned in a way no other man had ever been, I knew there was something different about me. But a king...

question: Phillippe... there is something I hope you understand. Terrible cruelty has been used against you. And... you must understand that you did nothing to deserve it.
answer: There is... wrath... in me. I have learned to hide it. Those years in the cell, I dreamed that freedom would someday just happen, the way the mask happened. Now I am free. And with each free breath I feel the growing desire to make someone suffer for all I lost. Look at this, all this that for ten years I could not see! What if I become a king -- a king no different from my brother?

question: The desire for vengeance... can be a poison.
answer: What is its antidote?

question: I suppose... it is to remember there are many people who have never been in a prison, who pass such beauty every day, and never see it.
answer: You look so sad. Is it something I have done?

question: It is something I have done -- or did not do.
answer: What is that?

question: I did not share beauty with someone... who is no longer here for me to share beauty with. We have much to do, we'd best get started. Now suppose you were to walk into a garden, as a king...
answer: More wine! How is he?

question: Resting, he's had a long day. Aramis --
answer: More wine!!

question: You must reconsider this plan. Phillippe is like a child, he --
answer: You can do it.

question: In a year, maybe two, I could teach him enough to --
answer: Three days.

question: Three days??!!
answer: The King is having a ball, a masquerade ball. It is the perfect opportunity and perhaps our only one. At any time Phillippe could be discovered, and what then? Remember France. Remember the poor. Remember Raoul. More wine!! Where are those serving girls...?

question: Phillippe -- he's very bright, he's perceptive, but he is in such turmoil --
answer: You grow fond of him. That's good.

question: Don't play God with me, Aramis I --
answer: Go on.

question: But -- what is Porthos doing?
answer: Going into the barn naked -- or so it appears. Now. You were saying?

question: But -- what is he doing?
answer: About to hang himself, I should think.

question: Hang himself?!
answer: He's threatened to do it, it's been building up in him for months.

question: We must stop him!
answer: Come now, Athos, if Porthos is determined to end his life, then he will certainly manage to find the opportunity.

question: A'dieu, cruel life! Farewell to useless Porthos!
answer: I sawed the main beam in half. I'm a genius -- not an engineer!

question: Aramis!! You did this, didn't you! You knew I would try hanging myself, and you sawed the beam! Admit it! Admit it, by God!! ADMIT IT!!!
answer: Well of course I knew it, Porthos. You've been moping for months. Now that you've gotten the idea of killing yourself out of the way, you can stop boring me and start being useful to me. Now get some rest.

question: Where are you going?!
answer: Paris. There is still much to do. We'll be back soon. Be ready.

question: But Aramis -- ! Phillippe can learn in time, but --
answer: He can learn to be Phillippe in time. But first he must learn to be Louis, and for that he has two more days.

question: What you're asking is impossible!
answer: I offer you the perfect revolution. A revolution without bloodshed, without any loss of life, even without treason, for he too is the son of the King.

question: But --
answer: You said you'd do anything, Athos, anything to replace this King. So do it.

question: No, wait, do not hold your goblet that way. With a king it is... so. It is not to be dainty. Servants have touched the King's goblet, so he will touch it as little as possible.
answer: I am so sorry! Forgive me, I --

question: No! Do not be sorry! Never be sorry! The King cares for nothing and for no one! There are no mistakes when you are King! What you do is right for every person! A King has contempt for everyone!
answer: Is that the king of king you wish me to be? Or do you say this because of your son?

question: How did you know -- ?
answer: Porthos told me.

question: Coming?
answer: What use am I?

question: We go someplace dangerous.
answer: Why didn't you say so? It is good to be out on a mission again... We are out on a mission, aren't we? You're right. Tell Porthos nothing. He needs to know nothing, for he is useless. Old? Old?! You're all trying to rob us because you think we're old? Old?! I'll show you old!! Let's see you rob somebody with your pistol there!

question: Come on...
answer: I have to tell you something. I love Paris!

question: Here we are.
answer: Aramis... These are... these are whores!

question: So was Mary Magdalene, and our Lord loved her.
answer: Did she have tits like that?

question: No. We want you, Father Belles. Bless me, Father, for I have sinned. I have sinned. And no other priest's assurance of forgiveness can mean as much as yours. Tell me that I can be forgiven, no matter what I have done.
answer: He's going to kill you, Aramis.

question: Your mother's.
answer: Change the horses! Clear out everything! NOW!!

question: Aramis, this will never --
answer: Louis is planning a visit to the Vatican, then who knows where after that. If we miss him now we may not get another chance.

question: But --
answer: It presses us but it is good for us too! Louis' whims make him more vulnerable. We are less ready, but so are his guards!

question: She'll be gone tomorrow. Mother -- ?
answer: May I speak with you? Alone?

question: I am preparing for a ball!
answer: We haven't visited in three years. And we should have privacy.

question: What is it, mother?
answer: I wish to discuss your brother.

question: He is dead! By God's choice! There is nothing to discuss.
answer: First they told me he had died at birth. Then your father admitted he was alive, but well cared for, in secret. But the message that told of his death said he had been a prisoner.

question: I am King, Mother! And I do not wish to discuss this with you.
answer: He was my blood -- and I demand to know what happened to him.

question: Why would you ask now? You never asked before!
answer: Because I have dreamed of him. Not as the baby they took away, but as a man.

question: You have prayed too much. Your mind is weak.
answer: I believe in dreams, Louis. They are our souls speaking to us, from that world beyond our eyes. And that son I never saw in daylight was standing in the moonlight of my dreams. And he wore an iron mask.

question: It -- it doesn't matter, Mother! He is dead now! Dead!
answer: Yes. Dead. Two nights ago. The night of my dream.

question: If... if he was wearing an iron mask in your dream, then how could you know he was your son?
answer: Then you did do it, Louis. You did put your brother in an iron mask.

question: It is Judgment Day.
answer: Wh-- Wha--

question: Don't look so shocked, Phillippe. Come, you're going back to prison.
answer: Phillippe?! Why do you call me --

question: Good night... my son.
answer: Anne! You look -- My Queen...

question: D'Artagnan.
answer: I have never seen a sight more beautiful than you, tonight.

question: We have much to discuss. Tomorrow.
answer: How long has the King been back?

question: sees d'Artagnan, staring at him... then calling more guards over and giving them quick instructions; the guards hurry away. Then d'Artagnan moves to Phillippe, and bows. He looks at him carefully, but seems to see nothing unusual. Continue.
answer: Sire, we have an emergency -- of security. I must ask you to accompany me.

question: ... The ball... Continue.
answer: I must insist, Sire. he stands with a small contingent of young Musketeers. His eyes are intense, his face in agony. My friends. Only we four, the most trusted Musketeers, knew about the passages, meant to keep the King safe... Your Majesty...

question: Shut up, knave!
answer: Before I came here, I insisted the King come with me. The real Louis would never have let me insist.

question: Pull them back, d'Artagnan.
answer: You can't do it.

question: Pull them back!
answer: Everyone back.

question: You will not shed royal blood! I want all these passages sealed! Another stupid idea of my father's! Seal them all, every one!
answer: It shall be done, your Majesty.

question: Even the bedchamber passages! Let none remain!
answer: Yes, your Majesty.

question: I was told this impostor was dead!
answer: ... You knew you had a double?

question: He is my brother.
answer: I -- I thought he was but... an impostor who resembled --

question: My twin. Which has kept him alive. Until now.
answer: Louis, please -- !

question: My guards are useless! Take her from me! What had you to do with this, Mother?
answer: He is your brother!

question: He is nothing now.
answer: Your Majesty... This man before you... He is royal blood, the same as you. To spill it is the one thing even you cannot do. It is against the laws of God, and of France.

question: Get out of my way.
answer: Not once have I ever asked anything for myself. I ask now. Forgive this man, this prisoner... your brother.

question: Forgive?!
answer: Aramis, Porthos and Athos too. I know what they have done was a threat against you -- and yet that threat has been removed, with no harm coming to your Majesty. If their passions were in error, their spirits have ever been noble. Forgive them.

question: They have plotted against me! Me! The embodiment of God's will!
answer: Your Majesty... Every day of your life, I have watched over you. No angel could have stood a more faithful vigil. I have bled for you, and have prayed, every day, to see you become greater than your office, better than the law. Show me now what my faith and blood have purchased. Show mercy.

question: He lures us to capture.
answer: He seeks redemption.

question: You're a fool!
answer: Perhaps. But of d'Artagnan I am certain. What he did tonight was what he told us all along he would do -- be faithful to his King.

question: So what has changed?
answer: Perhaps he serves a different king.
